The Record of the Improved Jones Stacker for the Season of 1902.

Not a complaint of any kind. No repairs asked for. Not a choke heard of. Not an expert sent for. Every Stacker settled for and every purchaser satisfied.

Jones Stacker Co., Carberry, Man.: Wawanesa, January 3rd, 1903.

Gentlemen— I operated one of your new Wind Stackers this season. It gave me the very best of satisfaction. From the time we attached it we never had a single stop on account of the Stacker. We have choked the Separator in long damp straw, but never the Blower. As for power to drive it, I don't think it takes over one horse power. It is the only Blower I have seen yet that will not choke some times. We have never had any trouble or expense whatever with it, and it will stack for half a day's good threshing with ease.

Yours truly, A. D. NAISMITH.

Jones Stacker Co., Carberry, Man.; Gentlemen.—I operated one of your new Wind Stackers this season. It gave me the very best of satisfaction. From the time we attached it, we never had a single stop, on account of the Separator in long damp straw, but however the Blower As the Stacker. We have choked the Separator in long damp straw, but the only Blower I have for power to drive it, I don't think it takes over one-horse power. It is this only Blower I have seen yet that will not choke some times. We have never had any trouble or expense what so ever with it, and it will stack for half a day's good threshing with ease.

Yours truly, A. D. NASHRTH.

THE CAR SHORTAGE.

For some years now it has annually fallen to our lot, during the wheat-shipping season, to discuss the question of a car shortage. It was our hope, however, that between the devastations wrought this year by rust in some of the Manitoba districts which have always been large producers of wheat, and the substantial improvements which for some time back the railway companies have been making in their equipment, we should this season be spared the necessity of again writing an article under this heading. But we have not been blessed with such good fortune.

The movement of wheat this year was considerably delayed at the first of the season, as is evidenced by the fact that the total number of cars inspection at Winnipeg during the month of September aggregated only 2,160 as against 3,089 cars dur-
THE CAR SHORTAGE.

For some years now it has annually fallen to our lot, during the wheat-shipping season, to discuss the question of a car shortage. It was our hope, however, that between the devastations wrought this year by rust in some of the Manitoba districts which have always been large producers of wheat, and the substantial improvements which for some time back the railway companies have been making in their equipment, we should this season be spared the necessity of again writing an article under this heading. But we have not been blessed with such good fortune.

The movement of wheat this year was considerably delayed at the first of the season, as is evidenced by the fact that the total number of cars inspection at Winnipeg during the month of September aggregated only 3,089 cars dur-
who has been connected with the history of the district from its early days, died suddenly on Oct. 21.

Saskatoon is endeavoring to raise $7,000 for a hospital and is inviting neighboring villages to contribute part of the amount in consideration of the benefits which would accrue to them on account of its presence. There is at present no hospital between Regina and Prince Albert.

A recent visitor to Lloydminster says the town seems to be flourishing. There are about 70 buildings, including several large stores. There is a scarcity of water in the town as it depends on wells for its supply. It is a prohibition town, intoxicants are not sold. The railway grade east of Lloydminster is nearly completed and most of the outfits have moved westward along the grade towards Vegreville.

MARKET REVIEW.

Winnipeg, Sept. 19, 1909.

The recent rains have delayed threshing and other outside work, as well as doing considerable damage to crops. The result of this has been to make the outlook for the market less promising than it was at our last report. However, while the outlook for grain is not bright, the dairy business continues to show unusually good prices, and the same conditions in one case brings the highest price the market can pay. Mercantile trade is quiet and the weekly bank clearings do not continue to show the increase in the volume of trade they have done in the past. Interest rates are firmer.

Wheat.

The wheat market quickened about the 10th, and has since with fluctuations kept a little stronger. Our Chicago quotations for Sept. 25 were for No. 1, 78c.; No. 2, 74c.; Nov., 78c.; Nov., 78c. The local conditions point to the bulk of the crop going from No. 2 hard down to No. 3 medium, being exposed to rain. This has given the stocks a bad look; but in some districts the grain when threshed is not so bad as it looked. The chaff keeps the berry in fairly good condition. The barometer looks well today and the outlook for threshing is improved accordingly. Buyers will be sent out as soon as the weather settles. Fort William is still high above export values; nominal figure now $4.60 per Sack.

Winnipeg, in car lots for week ending Sept. 8, 1909: No. 1 hard, 122 cars; No. 2 hard, 19 cars; No. 3 hard, 11 cars; inferior grades, 9 cars. Total, 161 cars.

Oats.

Present prices on track at Winnipeg are 88c. and 90c. One poor lot sold at 36c. No new offering. It is pretty certain that before the new crop reaches the consumer much of it will be more or less heated. If only slightly heated, such oats make very bad seed.

Barley.

Nothing offering. Nominal price, 50c.

Flour and Feed.

Ogilvie's Hungarian, per bag, $2.20; Glenora, per bag, $2.05; Manitoba, $1.60; Imperial, 5X, $1.25.

Oat chop, $25 per ton; cornmeal, $1.50 per bag; bran, $12.50 per ton; shorts, $15.50 per ton; barley chop, $21.50 per ton; corn chop, $22 per ton; rolled oats, $1.80 per 80 lbs.

Butter and Cheese.

The local market is unchanged. Creamery, 19c. at factories. The best quality of dairy is apparently being held back; ordinary lots run from 12c. to 14c.

Factory cheese runs from 9½c. to 10c., according to quality. Inferior lots command less.

Cattle.

Best quality, on foot, is $3.75. Inferior lots run from that down to $2.75.

Mutton.

On foot, 4c.; dressed, 9c. to 10c.

Hides.

No change; No. 1 inspection, 6c.

Eggs.

Practically no change since last report; 12½c. for fresh eggs delivered in Winnipeg is the going price.

Hogs.

Very little stock moving. The market remains firm at 5¼c. for choice selections. Thick fat hogs run at 4¼c. to 5c.
The wheat market quickened about the 100th and has since with fluctuations kept a little stronger. Our Chicago quotations for Sept. 3 were for O.C., Face, No. 1, $1.44; No. 2, $1.40; No. 3, $1.36. The best condition paint to the bulk of the crop going from No. 2 hard down to No. 3 northern, most expensive in the season, has gained on the grain while the latter is not so hard as it looked. The cliff keeps the berry in fairly good condition. The harbourer, boiler will be preserved as soon as the weather settles. Fert William is still high above export values; nominal figure now $4.50 to $5.00.

Winnipeg, Sept. 11, 1894.

Oats.

MARTIN HENDERSON, DOUGLASTON, ASSA., AND HIS FOUR OXEN AT WORK ON THE DISC HARROW.
Out Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Matherwell, Almira.

The following essay was awarded the first prize in the competition for the best method of growing oats or anything else, judged by Mr. J. H. Smith, of the Qu'Appelle Valley Agricultural Society. The essay was written by Mr. W. R. Matherwell, of Almira, and was entitled "Out Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley."

The essay begins with an introduction, followed by a detailed explanation of the methods used by Mr. Matherwell to grow oats successfully. It covers topics such as soil preparation, seed selection, planting techniques, and post-planting care. The essay concludes with a summary of the benefits of these methods and a call to action for others to adopt similar practices.

[Handwritten note:]
May we not also see how best to improve our own farms?
Out Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Hetherington, Altona.

The following essay was awarded the first prize offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society. It is not intended to be an exhaustive treatise on the subject, but rather a brief summary of what has been learned in the course of the writer's experience.

The essay begins with a discussion of the importance of growing crops in the Qu'Appelle Valley. The author emphasizes the need for proper soil preparation and the use of high-quality seeds. He also stresses the importance of proper cultivation techniques, such as timely planting and harvesting.

The essay then goes on to discuss the various crops that can be grown in the valley, including wheat, oats, barley, and flax. The author provides detailed information on the best practices for growing each crop, including seed selection, planting methods, and harvesting techniques.

Throughout the essay, the author provides practical advice and tips for farmers in the Qu'Appelle Valley. He encourages readers to experiment with different crops and cultivation methods to find what works best for their particular situation.

In conclusion, the essay serves as a valuable resource for farmers looking to improve their yields and profits. It provides a comprehensive guide to growing crops in the Qu'Appelle Valley, covering everything from seed selection to harvesting techniques.

[Handwritten note:]
This essay was written by W. R. Hetherington, Altona, and was submitted to the Indian Head Agricultural Society for consideration in their annual crop competition.
Out Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Macdonald, Athabasca.

The following essay was awarded first prize offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society, April 20th, 1911.

The essay offers a comprehensive guide to growing oats in the Qu'Appelle Valley. It covers various aspects such as soil preparation, seed selection, planting techniques, and harvesting methods. The author emphasizes the importance of proper care and attention to achieve successful oat cultivation.

The essay provides practical advice for farmers in the region, highlighting the benefits of growing oats and offering tips for maximizing yields. It also discusses the challenges faced by farmers and suggests solutions to overcome them.

Overall, the essay serves as a valuable resource for anyone interested in growing oats in the Qu'Appelle Valley, providing insights and guidance based on local experiences and expertise.
Oat Growing for the Qu’Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Motherwell, Abernethy,

Of course there is no cast iron method of growing oats or anything else; judgment must be used to meet the varying requirements of new and unexpected conditions.

After cultivation, next in natural order would be the question of seed variety, quality and quantity. The Banner oat is acknowledged to be the best all-round oat in the West. But of course many people have other fancies, the gratification of which would not particularly interfere with successful oat culture for home consumption. But if you purpose growing seed oats for sale, sow
Oat Growing for the Qu’Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Motherwell, Abernethy,

Of course there is no cast iron method of growing oats or anything else; judgment must be used to meet the varying requirements of new and unexpected conditions.

After cultivation, next in natural order would be the question of seed variety, quality and quantity. The Banner oat is acknowledged to be the best all-round oat in the West. But of course many people have other fancies, the gratification of which would not particularly interfere with successful oat culture for home consumption. But if you purpose growing seed oats for sale, sow
The following essay was awarded first prize in the competition for prizes offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society. At some points we have taken the liberty to abridge it.

The oat crop of this district has for years been a comparative failure, the principal reason being that every decently prepared acre of our land has been given to wheat and only the poorest used for oats. If we want a decent crop of oats we must treat them decently. We must give them all the care we can consistently with due regard to the proper course for this district, soil and climate both being taken into account, is to have two grain crops alternating with a year under summer fallow.

Looking to the conditions as we find them, I would recommend that half of the acreage intended for oats be sown on fallow, as soon after the first week of May the other half to be sown on fallow stubble — burned or unburned, ever, to dispense with burning stubble if possible. This can be done by either drilling in among stubble without cultivation if land is clean and free from native rubbish, or by cultivating stubble (Moose Jaw cultivator preferred) and sowing crosswise with disc drill.

To avoid the risk of mixing our oats with wheat or barley, I would use the stubble left by last year's oat crop. It is better to have two oat crops in succession than run the risk of having them mixed up with other grains, as is too commonly the case.

Should it be found desirable to spring plow for the sake of keeping down quack grass, rosebushes, etc., it is important to plough as early in the season as possible, about three or four inches deep, harrow immediately after plowing, and sow as soon as a half day's snowed under.

1. Do not bergridge.
2. Sow sound, well seed.
3. Sow on thin side of field two or three inches deep, harrow immediately after sowing, and sow as soon as a half day's snowed under.

The quality of seed oats is very important. Under no circumstances should frozen or heated oats be used — even though quite ripe. Formalin or bluetone should be given all seed of the latter being useless for purpose growing seed oats.

The quantity of seed to be sown is ample time for free sowing. The quantity of seed to be sown is given far too little thought, entering it is one of first importance. With wheat certain amount of plant variety is necessary. With wheat, a half-bushel per acre is sufficient. Many will have grown over 100 bushels per acre, but for home use, may be well ripened by harvesting, oats to moisture to carry to market. In harvesting, oats to field two or three inches deep, harrow immediately after sowing, and sow as soon as a half day's snowed under.
Oat Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Motherwell, Abernethy,

The following essay was awarded first prize in the competition for the prizes offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society. At some points we have taken the liberty to abridge it.

The oat crop of this district has for years been a comparative failure, the principal reason being that every decently prepared acre of our land has been given to wheat and only the poorest used for oats. If we want a decent crop of oats we must treat them decently. We must give them all the care we can consistently with due regard to the other crops of the farm, of which wheat is properly regarded as the most important. I take it for granted that the proper course for this district, soil and climate both being taken into account, is to have two grain crops alternating with a year under summer fallow.

Looking to the conditions as we find them, I would recommend that half of the acreage intended for oats be sown on fallow, as soon after the first week of May as the condition of the soil will permit. The other half to be sown on fallow stubble — burned or unburned, cultivated or uncultivated, according to circumstances and requirements of each particular case.

If weeds, either annual or biennial, are feared, and the success of the present crop only be considered, then burn stubble, cultivate and sow the same time, as mentioned above. I like however, to dispense with burning stubble if possible. This can be done by either drilling in among stubble without cultivation if land is clean and free from native rubbish, or by cultivating stubble (Moose Jaw cultivator preferred) and sowing crosswise with disc drill.

To avoid the risk of mixing our oats with wheat or barley, I would use the green side. It is better to have two oat crops in succession than run the risk of having them mixed up with other grams, as is too commonly the case.

Should it be found desirable to spring plow for the sake of keeping down quack grass, rosetistles, etc., it is important to plough as early in the season as possible, about three or four inches deep, harrow immediately after plowing, and sow as soon as a half days snowed under.

To summarize them:

1. Do not beudgegeed plot of fallow for a good oat crop at least.
2. Sow sound, well

3. Sow on thin side.
Oat Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Matherwell, Abernethy,

The following essay was awarded first prize in the competition for the prizes offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society. At some points we have taken the liberty to abridge it.

The oat crop of this district has for years been a comparative failure, the principal reason being that every decently prepared acre of our land has been given to wheat and only the poorest crop of oats we must treat them decently. If we want a decent crop of oats we must treat them decently. We must give them all the care we can consistently with due regard to the other crops of the farm, of which wheat is properly regarded as the most important. I take it for granted that the proper course for this district, soil and climate both being taken into account, is to have two grain crops alternating with a year under summer fallow.

Looking to the conditions as we find them, I would recommend that half of May as the condition of the soil will permit. The other half to be sown on fallow, as soon after the first week of May as the condition of the soil will permit. The acreage intended for oats will be measured bushels per acre than there are feared, and the success of the present crop only be considered, then burn stubble, cultivate and sow the same time, as mentioned above. I like burning stubble ever, to dispense with burning stubble if possible. This can be done by either drilling in among stubble without cultivation if land is clean and free from native rubbish, or by cultivating stubble (Moose Jaw cultivator preferred) and sowing crosswise with disc drill.

To avoid the risk of mixing our oats with wheat or barley I would use the stubble left by last year's oat crop. It is better to have two oat crops in succession than run the risk of having them mixed up with other grains, as is too commonly the case.

Should it be found desirable to spring plow for the sake of keeping down quack grass, rosebushes, etc., it is important to plough as early in the season as possible, about three or four inches deep, harrow immediately after seed.

1. Do not be too eager to get the crop out of the field two or three weeks before harvest, as this will prevent the grain from getting too hard and will make it easier to thresh.

2. Sow soundly, as this will ensure a good stand and a good yield.

3. Keep the oats clean and free from rubbish during the growing season, as this will prevent the grain from getting too hard and will make it easier to thresh.

4. Harvest the oats when they are ripe, as this will ensure a good yield.

5. Store the oats in a cool place, as this will prevent the grain from getting too hard and will make it easier to thresh.

6. Use a good quality of seed, as this will ensure a good yield.

7. Keep the oats clean and free from rubbish during the growing season, as this will prevent the grain from getting too hard and will make it easier to thresh.

8. Harvest the oats when they are ripe, as this will ensure a good yield.

9. Store the oats in a cool place, as this will prevent the grain from getting too hard and will make it easier to thresh.

10. Use a good quality of seed, as this will ensure a good yield.
Oat Growing for the Qu'Appelle Valley.

By W. R. Mutherwell, Abernethy,

The following essay was awarded first prize in the competition offered by the Indian Head Agricultural Society. At some points we have taken the liberty to abridge it.

The oat crop of this district has been a comparative failure, the principal reason being that every decently prepared acre of our land has been given to wheat and only the poorest used for oats. If we want a decent crop of oats we must treat them decently. We must give them all the care we can consistently with due regard to the climate both being taken into account. The proper course for this district, soil and climate both being taken into account, is to have two grain crops alternating with a year under summer fallow.

If weeds, either annual or biennial, are feared, and the success of the present crop only be considered, then burn stubble, cultivate and sow the same time, as mentioned above. I like, however, to dispense with burning stubble ever, to sowing crosswise with disc drill, and sowing crosswise with disc drill, according to circumstances and requirements of each particular case.

If weeds, either annual or biennial, are feared, and the success of the present crop only be considered, then burn stubble, cultivate and sow the same time, as mentioned above. I like, however, to dispense with burning stubble ever, to sowing crosswise with disc drill, and sowing crosswise with disc drill, according to circumstances and requirements of each particular case.

If late varieties have grown over the fallow and if they are not perfectly satisfied, then cut them up and sow them mixed up with other grains, as is too commonly the case.

Should it be found desirable to spring plow for the sake of keeping down quack grass, rosinsholes, etc., it is important to plough as early in the season as possible, about three or four inches deep, harrow immediately after plowing, and sow as soon as a half day's snowed under.

To summarize:

1. Do not sow on fallow.
2. Sow on fallow.
3. Sow on fallow.
The Farm Home of Geo. Glaister, near Prince Albert, Sask.

Prof. Fletcher, Central Expmtl. Farm, Ottawa.

G. H. V. Bulyea, Com., of Agriculture, N.W.T.
The Farm Home of Geo. Glaister, near Prince Albert, Sask.
I am not positive, but I believe Mr. Bulyea was Lt.-Gov. for awhile. Date 1900.
I am not positive, but I believe Mr. Bulgea was Lt.-Gov. for awhile. Date 1900.
Sore Shoulders.

The main cause, in fact, one might say the sole cause, of sore shoulders, is an improperly fitting collar. The way to get a perfectly fitting collar is to soak it over night in water. In the morning the leather will be soft and pliable. Wipe off the surplus water and fit the collar snugly and carefully and start to work with a sufficient load to perfectly adapt...

ALBERTA.

The fire was a very serious one between the C.P.R. and the C.N.R., both south of Woodside, Waskatenau, Alberta, on July 25th. The fire was caused by a spark from the C.P.R. train, which was running on the C.N.R. line. The fire was put out by the C.P.R. crew, but not before it had caused considerable damage to the C.N.R. line.

Manitoba.

Thirty-three new water mains were laid in Winnipeg last year. The city now has a total of 36 miles of water mains. The city council has approved a plan to extend the water system to the north end of the city.

News of the West.

The latest news from the west is that the Canadian Pacific Railway has completed its transcontinental line from coast to coast. The line will be opened for traffic on July 1st.

Manitoba.

Thirty-three new water mains were laid in Winnipeg last year. The city now has a total of 36 miles of water mains. The city council has approved a plan to extend the water system to the north end of the city.

News of the West.

The latest news from the west is that the Canadian Pacific Railway has completed its transcontinental line from coast to coast. The line will be opened for traffic on July 1st.
ASSINTBOIA:

The Balgonie Milling Co., Ltd., will build a flour mill at Balgonie. The capacity will be 425 barrels.

One of the Indian Head grain buyers purchased $10,000 worth of wheat in one deal from one farmer there.

About 25 men had to be engaged by the Mounted Police at Oxbow to extinguish a recent prairie fire.

The Indian Head Prairie Witness in different items in the same issue tells about one farmer there who threshed 17,000 bushels of wheat, another who has 16,000 bushels and another with 18,000.

The splendid barn, 80x40 feet, belonging to Robt. Gibson, Belmont, was recently burned. A threshing machine was at the time working in the yard, and a number of horses were in the stables. Some of the animals were not rescued.

The Napinka paper says that notwithstanding the 25 cent duty on wheat being hauled across the lines, some of the farmers along the border have found the American prices to be so much higher than those in Manitoba that it pays them to draw grain across. Last year a few of the American farmers farther west drew grain to the Canadian towns.

ASSINIBOIA.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the places years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (already answered) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer sod houses
- Pioneer school life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer hunting and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will likely have the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here may apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: Braithwaite Charles

2. Your address: 14th Avenue, Regina, Saskatchewan

3. Date: October 14, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: James Braithwaite

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1894

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: None

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you may use it as a small child): 15

11. Through military forces in the Rebellion of 1885.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Braithwaite, Charles

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March 1894

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. (Give name of place and country)

The Great Emigration from the Red River Colony 1870-1874

11. That all your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? (Please list those who came west after you.)

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan/Canadian Head?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
The older folks wrote back and forth.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
Curt Jan 29, 1908

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Some came when the Homestead rush was on. About 10 years after we came.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
The two Brothers Homesteaded about 5 miles N by E from here. Dad and my sister married a Homesteader of the same district. Around 1902.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
Prairie fires when we first came. Blizzards and getting lost for a couple of hours. Riding my horse of Wagon to the Brothers on their Homestead. Staying for the night because night overtook us. Stayed around the Wagon 4 horses and fought Mosquitoes. Have driven often and inadvertently was kicked by the same ox that knocked a former minister & agriculturist of ours. That was the nearest I ever got to a fist fight.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
Not very much in the early times. Had attended Church and visited friends. The Church I attended was 7 miles away about every other Sunday. Horse a horse & Buggy.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a place to settle? Home came before the homestead rush was on.

About 10 years after we came the homestead rush was on.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West like when they came and where they settled.

The two Brothers Homesteaded about 5 miles North of home.

Dad and my sister married a homesteader of the same district. Autumn 1902.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Prairie fires and storms we had to come through and how we got along.

24. Did you travel much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Not very much in the last 6 times I attended church and visited friends. The Plowed I attended 4 times + 2 by car.

About every other Sunday. House in town + 2 by car.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1908.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? Not a Ford model. In 1915.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Indian Head, 5 miles away.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.). Yes, and still trading there. More often buying interests go to Regina occasionally. We found much better means of travel now. Quite a number from Balcarres dealt here in the earlier times before 1903 or 1904. They also drew more to Indian Head and waited a week for empty cars to send them back.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Around once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Even since I can remember a lot used to go and still do on Sat. night.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. Ever since Eaton's started in 1897 and Montgomery Ward and they fit mostly by woods & Brian Valmore since the early days.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1936, from local telephone Co., Waskawake telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? When we first came to what is now Sask., it had to be with the idea of staying there was no way to get back but walk.
24. Then was the first car used in the community? [Blank]

25. If you owned a car before 1916, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? [Blank]

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

32. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate all that fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

33. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? [Blank]
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few moved to O.C. before that time; some retired and moved away.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, stayed and came at times. This is a pretty fair district having land N.W. North + 97 B. of town.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

One of the first to sign up with the local council being number 6 in the Rural Municipality in 1923.

Father Brother, the first transport driver in the Rebellion, who started the P.M. and Regina. He was also one of the first J.P.O. and school trustees for years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

None present except the above mentioned ones.

P.H. Holman who owned the first car, the first automobile around 1908. Lives on his farm that our school facility was located.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (2), (3), (4).

The school was built on land owned by Mr. H. Holman. He gave the building site & grounds. Before and suggested the name of his farm, Jubilee, he gave to the school. This was in 1904 and has been that ever since.

Post Office has always been Indian Head and was located in a small corner of a fence line when we first came.

We are located about 6 miles south of the Sheaffella River.

Other schools in Indian Head area are: Henry Slade, S.S. #1 Rolling, Goodwill, Katerpillar, Crest, Victoria, Fire Station, Willie, Crowe, Kent, Long, Winkler, etc., for the present, however, the population of today is smaller than it was for the previous years, like population of today, Squirrel Hills, we have lots of people around there. Living south, there's not much natural flight. Farmland would mean anything, the old timers of that day were all good settlers around there, though.
37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

None of interest except the above asked date over.

P.J. Holden who owned the first car of the first automobile around 1908. It was on his farm that our School Jubilee was located.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The school was built on land owned by Mr. O.H. Holden farmer. He gave the building site & grounds (2 acres) and suggested the name of his farm, Jubilee, be given to the school. This was in 1904 and has been that ever since.

Post Office has always been Indian Head and was located in a small corner of a store when we first came there. We are located about 6 miles south of the Sheafle River.

Other schools in Indian Head area are: Lemon Slope, Slightly Rolling, good soil; Katepwa, Cree Indian for "big apple"; Wilde Crocker, don't know unless it's the unusual lemon tree; population of this day Squinnell Hills, used to be lots of geophytes around there. Sunny South, open not much natural shade. Fairplay named because anything the old timers of that day were all good fellows around there, though.
37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

P.H. Holden who owned the first car of the first automobile around 1908. It was on his farm that our School Jubilee was located.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The school was built on land owned by Mr. P.H. Holden farmer. He gave the building site and grounds. The school was named after the name of his farm. Jubilee, he gave to the school. This was in 1904 and has been that ever since.

Post Office has always been Indian Head and was located in a small corner of a store when we first came.

We are located about 6 miles south of the Sheppelle river.

Other schools in Indian Head area are: Loring Slope, Slightly Rolling, good soil, Katepwa, Cree Indian for the opposite side, White Rock, I don't know unless it's the highest, like population of the day, Squaw Hill, used to be lots of people around there. Sunny South, Open not much natural shade. Fair Play, named because anything the old timers of that day were all good fellows around there, though.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I am enclosing some old newspaper pictures, but if they are any use to you, you are welcome to them.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ....... (indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

We have 5 children: James Murray, Gordon & Roy Braithwaite and Mrs M.J. Kew, farming around Jordan Head. Murray's children are Lloyd, Patricia & Ronald Gordon's are Leslie Allan & Douglas. Mrs. Kew's are Gerald Gary & Myrna. They all ride to school in 258 cars. I used to walk 5 miles.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

There are several. Telephone, Automobile, Radio, Rural Electrification, Highways and Roads, Tractors & tractors, equipment, combines, orch leaders, rubber tired wagons and trailers, etc.
